title: The great brain debate - Ted Altschuler

multiple-choice.question: What was the main topic of debate between Ernest Aubertin and Pierre Gratiolet in 1861?

options.label: A
options.text: The role of the pineal gland in the human brain

options.label: B
options.text: The location of memory and speech functions in the brain

options.label: C
options.text: The importance of phrenology in understanding brain function

options.label: D
options.text: The role of the hippocampus in creating memories

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with establishing the study of phrenology, which held that strong mental faculties corresponded to highly developed brain regions?

options.label: A
options.text: Pierre Flourens

options.label: B
options.text: Franz Joseph Gall

options.label: C
options.text: Jean-Baptiste Bouillaud

options.label: D
options.text: Paul Broca

multiple-choice.question: What was the conclusion of Pierre Flourens' experiment on animal brains, which challenged phrenology?

options.label: A
options.text: That damaging the cortex resulted in the loss of specific functions

options.label: B
options.text: That the cortex carried out brain functions as an entire unit

options.label: C
options.text: That the frontal lobe was responsible for speech production

options.label: D
options.text: That the temporal lobe was responsible for speech comprehension

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with mapping each piece of cortex associated with moving a part of the body?

options.label: A
options.text: Karl Wernicke

options.label: B
options.text: Eduard Hitzig

options.label: C
options.text: Gustav Fritsch

options.label: D
options.text: David Ferrier

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the type of language loss that results from injuring the area connecting the regions for speech production and comprehension?

options.label: A
options.text: Receptive aphasia

options.label: B
options.text: Expressive aphasia

options.label: C
options.text: Broca's aphasia

options.label: D
options.text: Wernicke's aphasia

title: How do scars form? - Sarthak Sinha

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the extracellular matrix (ECM) in healthy skin tissue and the ECM in scar tissue?

options.label: A
options.text: The ECM in healthy skin tissue is composed of more collagen than the ECM in scar tissue.

options.label: B
options.text: The ECM in healthy skin tissue is arranged in a single direction, while the ECM in scar tissue is arranged in a basket-weave formation.

options.label: C
options.text: The ECM in healthy skin tissue allows for better cell-to-cell communication and cell adhesion than the ECM in scar tissue.

options.label: D
options.text: The ECM in healthy skin tissue is composed of less collagen than the ECM in scar tissue.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the presence of excessive fibrous connective tissue in an organ?

options.label: A
options.text: Fibrosis

options.label: B
options.text: Scarring

options.label: C
options.text: Wound healing

options.label: D
options.text: Tissue regeneration

options.label: A
options.text: Cystic fibrosis

options.label: B
options.text: Pulmonary fibrosis

options.label: C
options.text: Cardiac fibrosis

options.label: D
options.text: Skin fibrosis

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of medical researchers studying wound healing and scar tissue formation?

options.label: A
options.text: To develop new treatments for scarring

options.label: B
options.text: To understand the causes of fibrosis

options.label: C
options.text: To learn how to control wound healing and scar tissue formation

options.label: D
options.text: To develop new cosmetic procedures for scar removal

options.label: A
options.text: Producing sweat

options.label: B
options.text: Controlling body temperature

options.label: C
options.text: Growing hair

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the largest organ in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: Liver

options.label: B
options.text: Brain

options.label: C
options.text: Skin

options.label: D
options.text: Heart

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate body temperature

options.label: B
options.text: To produce sweat

options.label: C
options.text: To provide protection

options.label: D
options.text: To grow hair

options.label: B
options.text: Fibrin

options.label: C
options.text: Collagen

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: D

title: Ideasthesia: How do ideas feel? - Danko Nikolić

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the phenomenon where people's senses seem to mingle together, allowing them to hear colors or taste sounds?

options.label: A
options.text: Synesthesia

options.label: B
options.text: Ideasthesia

options.label: C
options.text: Sensory overload

options.label: D
options.text: Cross-sensory experience

multiple-choice.question: According to research, what is the underlying mental phenomenon that enables synesthesia to occur?

options.label: A
options.text: A direct connection between parts of the brain responsible for sensory stimuli

options.label: B
options.text: A connection between ideas and senses, mediated through understanding of shapes, colors, and sounds

options.label: C
options.text: A heightened sense of awareness and attention

options.label: D
options.text: A genetic predisposition to sensory overload

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the network of associations that enables us to understand metaphors and organize our everyday experiences of colors, sounds, and other stimuli?

options.label: A
options.text: Ideasthesia

options.label: B
options.text: Synesthesia

options.label: C
options.text: Semantic network

options.label: D
options.text: Sensory network

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the relationship between our sensory perceptions and our conceptual understanding of the world?

options.label: A
options.text: Our sensory perceptions shape our conceptual understanding of the world

options.label: B
options.text: Our conceptual understanding of the world shapes our sensory perceptions

options.label: C
options.text: Our sensory perceptions and conceptual understanding of the world are separate and distinct

options.label: D
options.text: Our sensory perceptions and conceptual understanding of the world are simultaneous and interconnected

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential implication of the ideasthesia model for our understanding of consciousness and the mind-body problem?

options.label: A
options.text: It suggests that the mind is a separate, non-material entity piloting a machine of flesh

options.label: B
options.text: It suggests that the mind is a purely physical entity that can be reduced to brain activity

options.label: C
options.text: It suggests that our sensory experience of the world is an undifferentiated mass without a preexisting network of interrelated concepts

options.label: D
options.text: It suggests that our conceptual understanding of the world shapes our sensory perceptions and that the two are interconnected

title: Could comets be the source of life on Earth? - Justin Dowd

multiple-choice.question: What was the historical perception of comets in ancient times?

options.label: A
options.text: Comets were considered to be good omens, signaling prosperity and peace.

options.label: B
options.text: Comets were thought to be ill omens of war and famine, or the wrath of gods.

options.label: C
options.text: Comets were believed to be a sign of a change in season.

options.label: D
options.text: Comets were considered to be a natural phenomenon with no significance.

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of the icy chunks and small fragments found in the outer reaches of the Solar System?

options.label: A
options.text: They are leftovers from the formation of the Solar System 4.6 billion years ago.

options.label: B
options.text: They are fragments from a neighboring star system.

options.label: C
options.text: They are the result of a recent asteroid collision.

options.label: D
options.text: They are the remains of a dead planet.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the comet's core as it approaches the Sun?

options.label: A
options.text: The core becomes larger and more solid.

options.label: B
options.text: The core remains unchanged.

options.label: C
options.text: The core melts, releasing gas and steam that form a bright surrounding cloud.

options.label: D
options.text: The core disintegrates completely.

multiple-choice.question: What significant discovery was made in the rubble left by a meteorite that disintegrated above northern Canada?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of water molecules.

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of amino acids.

options.label: C
options.text: The presence of oxygen molecules.

options.label: D
options.text: The presence of carbon dioxide molecules.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the possible role of comets in the origin of life on Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: Comets may have delivered the building blocks of life, such as amino acids, to Earth.

options.label: B
options.text: Comets may have provided the energy necessary for life to emerge on Earth.

options.label: C
options.text: Comets may have created the conditions necessary for life to evolve on Earth.

options.label: D
options.text: Comets may have had no role in the origin of life on Earth.

What is the name of the point in Pi where six 9s appear in a row?

title: Is our climate headed for a mathematical tipping point? - Victor J. Donnay

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept that explains how a small change in one factor can lead to massive and unpredictable changes in other factors?

options.label: A
options.text: Mathematical equilibrium

options.label: B
options.text: Mathematical tipping point

options.label: C
options.text: Chaotic motion

options.label: D
options.text: Predictive modeling

options.label: A
options.text: The ball's motion becomes more predictable

options.label: B
options.text: The ball's motion remains the same

options.label: C
options.text: The ball's motion becomes chaotic and unpredictable

options.label: D
options.text: The ball's motion stops

options.label: A
options.text: The ball's motion represents the Earth's rotation

options.label: B
options.text: The table's shape represents the CO2 level and Earth's average temperature

options.label: C
options.text: The ball's motion represents the Earth's orbit

options.label: D
options.text: The table's shape represents the Earth's geography

options.label: B
options.text: 400-500 parts per million

options.label: C
options.text: 500-800 parts per million

options.label: D
options.text: 800-1000 parts per million

options.label: B
options.text: A slight increase in global average temperature

options.label: C
options.text: More extreme and intense weather events, less predictability, and less hospitability to human life

options.label: D

title: How do germs spread (and why do they make us sick)? - Yannay Khaikin and Nicole Mideo

multiple-choice.question: What are the different kinds of microscopic organisms referred to as "germs"?

options.label: A
options.text: Bacteria, fungi, and viruses

options.label: B
options.text: Bacteria, fungi, protozoa, and viruses

options.label: C
options.text: Fungi, protozoa, and viruses

options.label: D
options.text: Bacteria, protozoa, and viruses

multiple-choice.question: According to the trade-off hypothesis, what do germs evolve to maximize?

options.label: A
options.text: Their replication rate within a host

options.label: B
options.text: Their transmission rate to new hosts

options.label: C
options.text: Their overall success by achieving a balance between replication and transmission

options.label: D
options.text: Their virulence within a host

multiple-choice.question: Why is the rhinovirus that replicates at a moderate rate ("just right") more successful than the others?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it causes more severe symptoms

options.label: B
options.text: Because it is more easily transmitted to new hosts

options.label: C
options.text: Because it balances replication and transmission, allowing the host to remain mobile

options.label: D
options.text: Because it has a higher replication rate

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a germ that may benefit from harming its host, as it is transmitted by mosquitoes?

options.label: A
options.text: Rhinovirus

options.label: B
options.text: Plasmodium (malaria parasite)

options.label: C
options.text: Influenza virus

options.label: D
options.text: HIV

multiple-choice.question: According to Dr. Paul Ewald, what can be done to reduce the harmfulness of infectious diseases?

options.label: A
options.text: Eradicating germs through antibiotics and vaccines

options.label: B
options.text: Directing their evolution through simple disease-control methods

options.label: C
options.text: Increasing host mobility to reduce transmission

options.label: D
options.text: Reducing the replication rate of germs within hosts

title: Einstein's brilliant mistake: Entangled states - Chad Orzel

multiple-choice.question: What was Albert Einstein's contribution to physics in his 1935 paper coauthored with Boris Podolsky and Nathan Rosen?

options.label: A
options.text: Deriving the equation E=MC^2

options.label: B
options.text: Describing the phenomenon of entangled states

options.label: C
options.text: Explaining the theory of relativity

options.label: D
options.text: Introducing the concept of quantum information

multiple-choice.question: According to the EPR paper, what happens when you measure a particle and then repeat the measurement?

options.label: A
options.text: You get the same result as the first measurement

options.label: B
options.text: You get a random result that is not correlated with the first measurement

options.label: C
options.text: You have a 50% chance of getting a different result than the first measurement

options.label: D
options.text: The particle's state becomes indeterminate again

multiple-choice.question: What is the implication of entanglement according to Einstein's theory of relativity?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows for faster-than-light communication

options.label: B
options.text: It requires one particle to send a signal to the other at a speed greater than light

options.label: C
options.text: It is impossible because it defies the speed of light limit

options.label: D
options.text: It is a fundamental aspect of quantum mechanics

multiple-choice.question: Who figured out the key to testing the EPR argument and showed that the purely quantum approach predicts mixed measurement results?

options.label: A
options.text: Niels Bohr

options.label: B
options.text: Albert Einstein

options.label: C
options.text: John Bell

options.label: D
options.text: Boris Podolsky

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the experiments that tested the EPR prediction?

options.label: A
options.text: They found that quantum mechanics is incorrect

options.label: B
options.text: They found that the correlations between entangled particles can be explained by a deeper variable

options.label: C
options.text: They found that quantum mechanics is correct and the correlations are real

options.label: D
options.text: They found that the results are inconclusive

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Niels Bohr

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Dead

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are too heavy

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Because he was not the first European to visit the Americas

title: How do vitamins work? - Ginnie Trinh Nguyen

multiple-choice.question: What are vitamins, and why are they essential for the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: Vitamins are inorganic compounds that help the body build muscle and bone.

options.label: B
options.text: Vitamins are organic compounds that help the body capture and use energy.

options.label: C
options.text: Vitamins are organic compounds that the body needs to ingest in small amounts to keep functioning.

options.label: D
options.text: Vitamins are inorganic compounds that help the body heal wounds.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between water-soluble and fat-soluble vitamins?

options.label: A
options.text: Water-soluble vitamins are found in fatty foods, while fat-soluble vitamins are found in watery foods.

options.label: B
options.text: Water-soluble vitamins are dissolved in water, while fat-soluble vitamins are dissolved in fat.

options.label: C
options.text: Water-soluble vitamins are stored in the liver, while fat-soluble vitamins are stored in the kidneys.

options.label: D
options.text: Water-soluble vitamins are more essential for the body than fat-soluble vitamins.

multiple-choice.question: How do fat-soluble vitamins enter the bloodstream?

options.label: A
options.text: They are absorbed directly into the bloodstream from the digestive system.

options.label: B
options.text: They are attached to proteins that act as couriers, transporting them into the blood.

options.label: C
options.text: They are dissolved in water and then absorbed into the bloodstream.

options.label: D
options.text: They are stored in the liver and then released into the bloodstream.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to excess water-soluble vitamins in the body?

options.label: A
options.text: They are stored in the liver and fat cells.

options.label: B
options.text: They are passed out of the body via the kidneys.

options.label: C
options.text: They are converted into fat-soluble vitamins.

options.label: D
options.text: They are used to make energy for the body.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of Vitamin K in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: It helps make white blood cells to fight infection.

options.label: B
options.text: It gathers calcium and phosphorus to make bones.

options.label: C
options.text: It works as an antioxidant to get rid of elements that can damage cells.

options.label: D
options.text: It helps make proteins that clot blood.

options.text: Clairvoyance

options.label: C
options.text: Controlling a robotic arm with thoughts

options.label: D
options.text: Levitation

title: If matter falls down, does antimatter fall up? - Chloé Malbrunot

multiple-choice.question: What would happen if the hydrogen atom and the antihydrogen atom got too close to each other?

options.label: A
options.text: They would stick together.

options.label: B
options.text: They would repel each other.

options.label: C
options.text: They would disappear in a spark of energy.

options.label: D
options.text: They would become neutral.

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to detect the gravitational force acting on small particles like the antiproton or proton?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the particles are neutral.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the particles are charged.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the gravitational force is too strong.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the electromagnetic force is much greater.

multiple-choice.question: Why is the antihydrogen atom hard to find?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it's everywhere.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it's only found in certain materials.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it annihilates with matter into energy.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it's only recently been created in a lab.

multiple-choice.question: How was the antihydrogen atom created in the lab?

options.label: A
options.text: By combining a proton and an electron.

options.label: B
options.text: By combining an antiproton and a positron.

options.label: C
options.text: By decaying a material that emits antiprotons.

options.label: D
options.text: By using a special machine to create antimatter.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the experiment with the hydrogen atom and the antihydrogen atom?

options.label: A
options.text: To measure the gravitational force acting on small particles.

options.label: B
options.text: To study the properties of antimatter.

options.label: C
options.text: To reenact Galileo's experiment with matter and antimatter.

options.label: D
options.text: To create a new source of energy.

title: Who speaks Wukchumni? A vanishing Native American language

options.label: A
options.text: November 24th, 1923

options.label: B
options.text: November 24th, 1933

options.label: C
options.text: November 24th, 1943

options.label: D
options.text: November 24th, 1953

multiple-choice.question: Why did Marie Wilcox start working on a dictionary for her native language?

options.label: A
options.text: She wanted to save it for future generations to learn.

options.label: B
options.text: She wanted to get all the words together for herself.

options.label: C
options.text: She was asked by her community to create a dictionary.

options.label: D
options.text: She wanted to prove that her language was still relevant.

multiple-choice.question: What was the most challenging sound for Marie Wilcox and her daughter to work with while creating the dictionary?

options.label: A
options.text: The TR sound

options.label: B
options.text: The CH H sound

options.label: C
options.text: The X sound

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: 5 years

options.label: C
options.text: 7 years

options.label: D
options.text: 10 years

options.text: To teach the language to other community members.

options.label: B
options.text: To archive and document the language for future generations.

options.label: C
options.text: To create a language learning program.

options.label: D
options.text: To translate the dictionary into other languages.

title: Cloudy climate change: How clouds affect Earth's temperature - Jasper Kirkby

multiple-choice.question: What is the expected rise in global temperatures by the end of the 21st century if carbon dioxide concentrations in the atmosphere double?

options.label: A
options.text: 0.5 to 1.5 degrees Celsius

options.label: B
options.text: 1.5 to 4.5 degrees Celsius

options.label: C
options.text: 2.5 to 5.5 degrees Celsius

options.label: D
options.text: 3.5 to 6.5 degrees Celsius

multiple-choice.question: What is the main source of uncertainty in Earth's climate sensitivity?

options.label: A
options.text: Greenhouse gas concentrations

options.label: B
options.text: Aerosol particles in clouds

options.label: C
options.text: Pre-industrial cloudiness

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of aerosol particles in cloud formation?

options.label: A
options.text: They block out the sun in polluted urban environments

options.label: B
options.text: They bathe distant mountains in a blue haze

options.label: C
options.text: A cloud droplet cannot form without an aerosol particle seed

options.label: D
options.text: They have no effect on cloud formation

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the "Cloud" experiment at CERN?

options.label: A
options.text: To study the effects of greenhouse gases on climate change

options.label: B
options.text: To investigate the formation of aerosol particles in the atmosphere

options.label: C
options.text: To measure the radiative forcing of the present day climate

options.label: D
options.text: To predict the change in temperature with precision

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the questions that the "Cloud" experiment aims to address?

options.label: A
options.text: How do aerosol particles affect the formation of clouds?

options.label: B
options.text: Could the puzzling observations of solar climate variability in the pre-industrial climate be explained by an influence of galactic cosmic rays on clouds?

options.label: C
options.text: How much have clouds changed due to human activities?

options.label: D
options.text: What is the effect of aerosol particles on the climate?

title: How cosmic rays help us understand the universe - Veronica Bindi

multiple-choice.question: How far away can the Hubble Telescope see objects in space?

options.label: A
options.text: 1,000,000 light years away

options.label: B
options.text: 13,000,000,000 light years away

options.label: C
options.text: 100,000,000 light years away

options.label: D
options.text: 1,000,000,000 light years away

options.text: Victor Hess

options.label: B
options.text: Albert Einstein

options.label: C
options.text: Galileo Galilei

options.label: D
options.text: Isaac Newton

options.label: A
options.text: Photons that make up light rays

options.label: B
options.text: High-energy particles

options.label: C
options.text: Magnetic shockwaves

options.label: D
options.text: Black holes

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: To measure the velocity, trajectory, radiation, mass, and energy of cosmic ray particles

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: 50 million

options.label: C
options.text: 100 million

options.label: D

title: Where do genes come from? - Carl Zimmer

multiple-choice.question: How many genes are approximately present in human DNA?
What is the primary source of new genes on Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: Genetic mutations from exposure to radiation

options.label: B
options.text: Genetic material from other planets

options.label: C
options.text: Mistakes during cell division, such as copying the same stretch of DNA twice

options.label: D
options.text: Viral infections that introduce new genetic material

multiple-choice.question: What can happen to a duplicated gene over time?

options.label: A
options.text: It remains identical to the original gene

options.label: B
options.text: It becomes non-functional and is removed from the genome

options.label: C
options.text: It picks up new mutations that can change its function

options.label: D
options.text: It is only expressed in specific tissues or organs

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a gene that has evolved to have a new function in snakes?

options.label: A
options.text: A gene that makes a protein for killing bacteria in the pancreas

options.label: B
options.text: A gene that makes a protein for killing bacteria in the mouth

options.label: C
options.text: A gene that makes a venom in the pancreas

options.label: D
options.text: A gene that makes a venom in the mouth that was originally for killing bacteria in the pancreas

multiple-choice.question: What can happen to non-coding stretches of DNA?

options.label: A
options.text: They are always removed from the genome

options.label: B
options.text: They can mutate and become coding regions

options.label: C
options.text: They are only expressed in specific tissues or organs

options.label: D
options.text: They are only found in animal genomes

title: The history of tattoos - Addison Anderson

multiple-choice.question: What is the origin of the word "tattoo" in the English language?

options.label: A
options.text: From the Greek word for "body art"

options.label: B
options.text: From the Polynesian word "tatao" used in Tahiti

options.label: C
options.text: From the Latin word for "scarring"

options.label: D
options.text: From the Egyptian word for "body modification"

multiple-choice.question: In ancient Greece and Rome, tattoos were often used to:

options.label: A
options.text: Signify wealth and status

options.label: B
options.text: Identify soldiers and military personnel

options.label: C
options.text: Discourage escape and desertion among slaves and mercenaries

options.label: D
options.text: Symbolize spirituality and cultural heritage

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the numbers tattooed on the arms of Holocaust survivors?

options.label: A
options.text: They were used to identify prisoners in concentration camps

options.label: B
options.text: They were used to signify resistance against the Nazi regime

options.label: C
options.text: They were used to track the number of survivors

options.label: D
options.text: They were used to identify the survivors' nationalities

multiple-choice.question: In traditional Maori culture, what was the significance of an unfinished tattoo?

options.label: A
options.text: It symbolized spiritual growth and development

options.label: B
options.text: It signified cowardice and lack of courage

options.label: C
options.text: It represented a rite of passage into adulthood

options.label: D
options.text: It was a symbol of wealth and status

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: What is the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle? - Chad Orzel

multiple-choice.question: What is the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle?

options.label: A
options.text: A principle that states the exact position and speed of an object can be known simultaneously.

options.label: B
options.text: A principle that states the act of measuring an object's position changes its speed.

options.label: C
options.text: A principle that states the exact position and speed of an object cannot be known simultaneously.

options.label: D
options.text: A principle that states the act of measuring an object's speed changes its position.

multiple-choice.question: Why do everyday objects not exhibit wave-like behavior?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are too small.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are too heavy.

options.label: C
options.text: Because their wavelengths are too short to detect.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are too fast.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when waves with different wavelengths are combined?

options.label: A
options.text: The waves cancel each other out.

options.label: B
options.text: The waves create a bigger wave.

options.label: C
options.text: The waves create a wave packet with a clear wavelength in one small region.

options.label: D
options.text: The waves do not interact with each other.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the uncertainty of position and momentum?

options.label: A
options.text: As the uncertainty of position increases, the uncertainty of momentum decreases.

options.label: B
options.text: As the uncertainty of position decreases, the uncertainty of momentum increases.

options.label: C
options.text: The uncertainty of position and momentum are not related.

options.label: D
options.text: The uncertainty of position and momentum are always equal.

multiple-choice.question: What is the nature of the uncertainty in the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a practical limit on measurement.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a result of the act of measurement.

options.label: C
options.text: It is an inevitable result of combining particle and wave nature.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a result of the observer effect.

title: Particles and waves: The central mystery of quantum mechanics - Chad Orzel

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with explaining the colors of light emitted by hot objects, like the filament in a light bulb, by introducing the concept of discrete chunks of energy?

options.label: A
options.text: Albert Einstein

options.label: B
options.text: Max Planck

options.label: C
options.text: Niels Bohr

options.label: D
options.text: Ernest Rutherford

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Ernest Marsden and Hans Geiger's experiment, where they shot alpha particles at gold atoms?

options.label: A
options.text: The alpha particles passed through the gold atoms without any deflection.

options.label: B
options.text: The alpha particles were absorbed by the gold atoms.

options.label: C
options.text: Some alpha particles bounced straight backwards.

options.label: D
options.text: The gold atoms emitted X-rays.

multiple-choice.question: According to Niels Bohr's model, when do atoms absorb and emit light?

options.label: A
options.text: When electrons are in certain special orbits.

options.label: B
options.text: When electrons change orbits.

options.label: C
options.text: When electrons emit X-rays.

options.label: D
options.text: When electrons spiral into the nucleus.

multiple-choice.question: Who proposed that electrons behave like waves, which helped explain Bohr's rule for picking out special orbits?

options.label: A
options.text: Louis de Broglie

options.label: B
options.text: Albert Einstein

options.label: C
options.text: Niels Bohr

options.label: D
options.text: Ernest Rutherford

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of shooting single electrons at a barrier with slits cut in it, demonstrating the wave-particle duality of electrons?

options.label: A
options.text: Each electron is detected at a specific place at a specific time, with no pattern emerging.

options.label: B
options.text: Each electron is detected at a specific place at a specific time, tracing out a pattern of stripes.

options.label: C
options.text: The electrons are absorbed by the barrier.

options.label: D
options.text: The electrons emit X-rays.

title: The chemistry of cold packs - John Pollard

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason a cold pack can go from room temperature to near freezing in a short time?

options.label: A
options.text: An exothermic reaction that releases heat from its surroundings.

options.label: B
options.text: An endothermic reaction that absorbs heat from its surroundings.

options.label: C
options.text: A chemical reaction that changes the state of the substance.

options.label: D
options.text: A physical reaction that changes the temperature of the substance.

multiple-choice.question: What are the two driving forces behind chemical processes?

options.label: A
options.text: Energetics and entropy.

options.label: B
options.text: Temperature and pressure.

options.label: C
options.text: Kinetic energy and potential energy.

options.label: D
options.text: Attractive and repulsive forces.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the particles in a substance when the attractive forces between them are strong?

options.label: A
options.text: They move rapidly away from each other.

options.label: B
options.text: They move rapidly towards each other.

options.label: C
options.text: They vibrate back and forth.

options.label: D
options.text: They remain stationary.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the solid in a cold pack dissolve in water, despite the interactions between the solid particles and water molecules being weaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the attractive forces between the particles are strong enough to overcome the weaker interactions.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the entropy of the system favors the mixing of the solid and water.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the temperature of the system increases.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the kinetic energy of the particles decreases.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the random motion of particles in a cold pack?

options.label: A
options.text: The particles return to their solid state.

options.label: B
options.text: The particles separate and mix with the water, resulting in a colder solution.

options.label: C
options.text: The particles move rapidly towards each other, increasing the temperature.

options.label: D
options.text: The particles remain stationary, maintaining the same temperature.
